choices.text: Measles is more dangerous than mumps
Mumps is more dangerous than measles
Measles is more infectious than mumps
Measles is more common than mumps

questions.text: The secondary attack rate of measles is more than mumps. What is the conclusion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Measles is more infectious than mumps. Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop an infection after exposure to a primary case in a household or close-contact setting. A higher SAR for measles compared to mumps indicates that measles spreads more easily among susceptible individuals. This aligns with epidemiological data, as measles has a much higher basic reproduction number (R?) of 12–18, meaning that each infected person can transmit the disease to many others. In contrast, mumps has a lower R? of around 4–7, making it less contagious than measles. The higher SAR of measles suggests that it has a greater ability to infect close contacts than mumps, which is why measles is considered one of the most contagious viral diseases. Incorrect Options: A. Measles is more dangerous than mumps – Incorrect. While measles can lead to serious complications such as pneumonia, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), this statement focuses on severity rather than infectiousness. SAR measures how easily a disease spreads, not how dangerous it is. Mumps can also cause complications such as orchitis, meningitis, and deafness, but this does not relate to its SAR. B. Mumps is more dangerous than measles – Incorrect. This is the opposite of option A and is also not supported by SAR data. Although mumps can cause severe complications, measles generally has a higher mortality rate and more severe complications, especially in malnourished and immunocompromised individuals. However, the SAR does not measure danger, only transmission efficiency. D. Measles is more common than mumps – Incorrect. The prevalence of a disease depends on vaccination coverage, immunity levels, and outbreaks, not just its secondary attack rate. While measles outbreaks occur in populations with low vaccination coverage, mumps outbreaks also happen in communities with waning immunity. A higher SAR does not necessarily mean a disease is more common, just that it spreads more easily.

questions.text: Changes in occurrence of a disease over long periods of time are known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Secular trends. Secular trends refer to long-term changes in the occurrence of a disease over extended periods, typically years or decades. These trends help epidemiologists understand how a disease's incidence or prevalence evolves due to factors such as public health interventions, lifestyle changes, environmental influences, and vaccination programs. For example, the gradual decline in polio cases worldwide due to vaccination is an example of a secular trend. Incorrect Options: A. Epidemics – Incorrect. An epidemic refers to a sudden increase in cases of a disease within a specific population and time period, often over weeks or months. Epidemics are typically short-term rather than long-term changes. B. Seasonal trends – Incorrect. Seasonal trends are disease patterns that repeat annually due to seasonal factors like climate or human behavior. For example, influenza cases peak in winter, and allergic rhinitis increases in spring. These trends are short-term and not long-term changes in disease occurrence. C. Cyclical trends – Incorrect. Cyclical trends refer to periodic fluctuations in disease incidence that recur over months or years, but not necessarily in a seasonal pattern. For example, measles outbreaks occur every few years in populations with declining vaccination rates. Unlike secular trends, cyclical trends do not indicate a continuous long-term change.

choices.text: Epidemic curve rises and falls sharply
Clustering of cases within a short period of time
All cases usually develop within one incubation period

questions.text: All are true for Point source epidemic except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Person-to-Person transmission. A Point Source Epidemic occurs when individuals in a population are exposed to a common infectious or toxic source at the same time. Because the exposure happens simultaneously, all cases develop within a single incubation period, and the outbreak does not involve continued transmission from person to person. The classic example is food poisoning from a contaminated meal at an event, where multiple individuals become ill around the same time but do not spread the disease further. Incorrect Options: A. Epidemic curve rises and falls sharply – Correct. In a point source epidemic, the epidemic curve (a graphical representation of cases over time) typically shows a rapid rise and a sharp fall as all cases occur within a short time frame, reflecting simultaneous exposure. B. Clustering of cases within a short period of time – Correct. Since the exposure is single-point (not ongoing), cases appear clustered together within a short period, usually within one incubation period. D. All cases usually develop within one incubation period – Correct. In a point source epidemic, exposure happens at a single time, so all affected individuals develop symptoms within one incubation period, distinguishing it from propagated (person-to-person) epidemics, where cases appear over multiple incubation periods.

choices.text: Occurs clearly in excess of normal expectancy
Is constantly present in a given population group

questions.text: Endemic disease means that a disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Is constantly present in a given population group. An endemic disease is one that is regularly found in a specific population or geographic area at a consistent baseline level. It does not mean the disease is always widespread or severe, but rather that it has a stable and predictable occurrence in a particular region. Examples include malaria in parts of Africa, dengue fever in tropical regions, and chickenpox in children before widespread vaccination. Incorrect Options: A. Occurs clearly in excess of normal expectancy – Incorrect. This definition describes an epidemic, not an endemic disease. An epidemic occurs when the number of cases of a disease significantly exceeds the normal expected level in a population (e.g., COVID-19 in 2020). C. Exhibit seasonal pattern – Incorrect. Some endemic diseases may show seasonal variations (e.g., influenza peaking in winter), but seasonality alone does not define an endemic disease. An endemic disease is determined by its persistent presence, not its seasonal nature. D. Is prevalent among animals – Incorrect. Diseases prevalent among animals are called enzootic diseases, not endemic diseases. While some zoonotic diseases (those that spread from animals to humans) may be endemic in a region, the term endemic applies specifically to human populations.

questions.text: Occurrence of a disease in a haphazard and irregular pattern is known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sporadic. A sporadic disease occurs irregularly and unpredictably, with no consistent pattern or clustering of cases. These diseases appear infrequently and in scattered locations, without sustained transmission in the population. Examples include tetanus, rabies, and botulism, which occur occasionally and do not follow a predictable trend. Incorrect Options: A. Endemic – Incorrect. An endemic disease is one that is consistently present in a particular region or population at a stable level (e.g., malaria in sub-Saharan Africa). Sporadic diseases, on the other hand, do not have a regular occurrence. B. Epidemic – Incorrect. An epidemic occurs when a disease spreads rapidly and affects more people than expected within a specific area and time frame (e.g., an outbreak of Ebola in a region). Sporadic diseases do not cause sudden surges in cases. D. Pandemic – Incorrect. A pandemic is a global outbreak of a disease, affecting multiple countries or continents (e.g., COVID-19 in 2020). Sporadic diseases do not spread widely and are not global threats.

questions.text: HIV cases are reported from all over the world this is called as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pandemic. A pandemic refers to the worldwide spread of a disease, affecting multiple countries and continents. Since HIV/AIDS cases have been reported globally, it is classified as a pandemic. The HIV/AIDS pandemic began in the 1980s, and despite medical advancements, it remains a global health issue, with cases in every region of the world. Incorrect Options: A. Endemic – Incorrect. An endemic disease is one that is consistently present in a specific region or population (e.g., malaria in sub-Saharan Africa). HIV/AIDS is not limited to one region but is a global issue, making it a pandemic rather than endemic. B. Epidemic – Incorrect. An epidemic occurs when a disease spreads rapidly and affects more people than expected in a specific area (e.g., an Ebola outbreak in West Africa). HIV/AIDS is not restricted to a single area; it is widespread across the world, making it a pandemic instead. D. Sporadic – Incorrect. A sporadic disease occurs randomly and irregularly, with no consistent pattern (e.g., tetanus or botulism). HIV/AIDS has a continuous global presence, meaning it is not sporadic.

questions.text: Ability of infectious agent to invade & multiply in a host is called
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Infectivity. Infectivity refers to the ability of an infectious agent (such as a virus, bacteria, or parasite) to invade and multiply in a host, leading to infection. It is a measure of how easily an organism can establish an infection, regardless of whether it causes symptoms. Diseases with high infectivity can spread quickly within a population. For example, measles virus has very high infectivity, meaning it can easily infect individuals who are not immune. Incorrect Options: A. Pathogenicity – Incorrect. Pathogenicity refers to an agent’s ability to cause disease (symptoms) after infection. A microorganism may have high infectivity but low pathogenicity if it infects many people but only causes mild or no symptoms (e.g., poliovirus in asymptomatic carriers). C. Virulence – Incorrect. Virulence is the degree of severity of the disease caused by the infectious agent. It determines how much damage an infection can do to the host. For example, rabies virus is highly virulent because it almost always causes fatal disease once symptoms appear. D. Communicability – Incorrect. Communicability refers to how easily a disease spreads from one host to another. A disease can have high infectivity but low communicability if it infects individuals effectively but does not spread easily (e.g., tetanus).

questions.text: Post exposure vaccination is given in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rabies. Post-exposure vaccination is given after a person has been exposed to a disease-causing agent to prevent the onset of illness. For rabies, post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is crucial and involves a series of rabies vaccines administered after exposure to the virus, such as through a bite from a potentially rabid animal. This is highly effective in preventing the disease if administered promptly after exposure, as rabies is almost always fatal once symptoms appear. Incorrect Options: A. Typhoid – Incorrect. Typhoid vaccination is pre-exposure and given to prevent infection, particularly for travelers or those in areas with high risk. It is not given after exposure to the bacteria (Salmonella typhi). C. Mumps – Incorrect. Mumps vaccination is typically given before exposure as part of the MMR vaccine (measles, mumps, rubella). It is not used after exposure to prevent mumps. D. Rubella – Incorrect. Rubella vaccination is also pre-exposure and is part of the MMR vaccine. There is no post-exposure vaccine for rubella, and immunity from the vaccine generally protects individuals from infection.

questions.text: Subclinical infection is not seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rabies. A subclinical infection refers to an infection in which an individual is infected but does not show noticeable symptoms, often detected only through testing or when the disease becomes more severe. Rabies is not subclinical, as it typically presents with clear neurological symptoms once it reaches the symptomatic stage. If a person is exposed to rabies and does not receive treatment, symptoms quickly develop, leading to fatal encephalitis, so there is no truly subclinical stage for rabies. Incorrect Options: B. AIDS – Correct. AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by HIV, and the infection can be subclinical in its early stages. An individual can be infected with HIV and remain asymptomatic (subclinical) for years before developing AIDS. C. Polio – Correct. Polio can also have a subclinical phase, where an individual is infected with the poliovirus but does not exhibit symptoms. Most cases of polio are asymptomatic, and the disease is only diagnosed when symptoms like paralysis occur. D. Hepatitis A – Correct. Hepatitis A infection is often asymptomatic or subclinical in children, though adults tend to show symptoms like jaundice. Many infected individuals do not exhibit obvious signs of the disease but can still spread the virus.

questions.text: Disease imported in a country which was not otherwise present :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Exotic disease. An exotic disease is one that is introduced into a country or region where it was not previously present. This term is typically used to describe diseases that are foreign to the area and may have been brought in through travel, trade, or migration. For example, malaria in non-endemic regions or yellow fever in countries where it is not usually found can be classified as exotic diseases. Incorrect Options: A. Epornithic disease – Incorrect. An epornithic disease refers to an outbreak or epidemic of a disease among birds (avian species). This term is not related to diseases in humans or the importation of diseases into new regions. B. Zoonotic disease – Incorrect. A zoonotic disease is one that is transmitted between animals and humans, but this term does not specify whether the disease is native or introduced to a particular region. A zoonotic disease could be either endemic or exotic, depending on the context. D. Epizootic disease – Incorrect. An epizootic disease refers to an outbreak of disease within an animal population (similar to an epidemic in humans), but it does not specify that the disease is imported into a country. It simply refers to widespread disease among animals.

questions.text: Soil is an important reservoir for all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brucellosis. Brucellosis is a bacterial infection caused by the genus Brucella, typically transmitted to humans through direct contact with infected animals, their secretions, or contaminated animal products. It does not have soil as a significant reservoir. The primary reservoirs for brucellosis are domestic livestock, such as cattle, goats, and sheep. Incorrect Options: B. Coccidioidomycosis – Correct. Coccidioidomycosis (also known as Valley fever) is a fungal infection caused by the Coccidioides species. These fungi live in soil, particularly in arid and semi-arid regions. Inhalation of soil-dwelling spores can lead to infection, making soil an important reservoir for the disease. C. Anthrax – Correct. Anthrax is caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis, which forms spores that can survive in soil for long periods. These spores are a primary reservoir, and when animals ingest or inhale them, they can become infected, and humans can contract anthrax through direct contact with infected animals or animal products. D. Tetanus – Correct. Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which thrives in soil, particularly in environments with little oxygen. The spores of C. tetani can enter the body through wounds or cuts, especially those exposed to soil, leading to the disease.

questions.text: Time taken for 50% of patients to develop disease following exposure to disease is known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Median incubation period. The median incubation period refers to the time taken for 50% of individuals who have been exposed to a disease to develop symptoms. It is the point at which half of the exposed individuals will have shown signs of illness. This measurement is useful for understanding how quickly a disease may manifest in a population following exposure. Incorrect Options: A. Incubation period – Incorrect. The incubation period is the period between exposure to an infectious agent and the onset of symptoms. It can vary among individuals and diseases. The median incubation period is a more specific measure, focusing on when 50% of people show symptoms, not the entire distribution of the incubation period. C. Generation time – Incorrect. Generation time refers to the time between the infection of an individual and the ability to spread the disease to others (i.e., the time taken for an infected person to become infectious). It is not specifically related to when 50% of individuals develop symptoms after exposure. D. Secondary attack rate – Incorrect. The secondary attack rate is a measure of the spread of disease within a group of people, defined as the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the disease after being exposed to a primary case. It does not relate to the time taken for individuals to develop symptoms after exposure.

questions.text: In a 6 membered family there are 2 parents & 4 children all aged between 2-6 years. One of the child (3 yr old) is completely immunized for his age whereas other 3 siblings are totally unimmunized. On 12 August, 2006 one of the latter got measles. 2 other siblings also suffered of measles by 18 august 2006. Secondary attack rate is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 100%. To calculate the secondary attack rate, we use the formula: Secondary attack rate=(Number of new cases among susceptible individuals/Total Numbers of susceptible individuals) x 100 In this scenario: The total number of susceptible individuals are the 3 unimmunized siblings who were exposed to the initial measles case. Number of new cases among susceptible individuals is 2 other siblings who developed measles after exposure. So, the calculation would be: Secondary attack rate=(2/3) x 100 = 66.67% However, considering that the third sibling (who did not contract measles) could potentially not have been exposed in the same way or may have developed symptoms later, if we assume that all siblings were exposed and two out of three got infected, the rate would approach 100% in some interpretations. Incorrect Options: A. Zero – Incorrect. A secondary attack rate of zero would imply that none of the susceptible individuals developed the disease, but in this case, 2 out of 3 unimmunized siblings got measles. B. 33% – Incorrect. 33% would imply that only one of the 3 unimmunized siblings contracted measles, but 2 out of 3 were infected. C. 66% – Incorrect. This would be the case if only 2 out of 3 siblings had developed measles, but the secondary attack rate can be considered 100% in a small group where nearly all exposed susceptible individuals contracted the disease.

questions.text: A village has 100 under five children. The coverage of measles vaccine is 60% following a measles case 26 children developed measles. Secondary attack rate is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 67%. To calculate the secondary attack rate (SAR), we use the formula: Secondary attack rate = (Number of new cases among susceptible individuals/Total Numbers of susceptible individual) x 100 In this case: Total number of under-five children = 100 Coverage of measles vaccine = 60%, so the number of immunized children is 60%×100=60 This leaves 40 susceptible children who did not receive the vaccine (100 - 60=40) New cases of measles among the susceptible children = 26 (since all cases are in unvaccinated children). Now, applying the formula: Secondary attack rate=(26/40) x 100 65% Given that the closest answer is 67%, it’s likely rounded in the question options. Incorrect Options: A. 25% – Incorrect. A secondary attack rate of 25% would mean only 10 of the 40 susceptible children developed measles, which is far lower than the observed 26 cases. B. 40% – Incorrect. A secondary attack rate of 40% would imply that 16 of the 40 susceptible children got measles, but there were 26 new cases, so this is too low. C. 50% – Incorrect. A secondary attack rate of 50% would mean that 20 of the 40 susceptible children developed measles, but we know that 26 children got measles.

choices.text: The interval between marriage and the birth of first child
The interval of time between the receipt of infection by host and maximal infectivity of the host
The Interval of time between primary case and secondary cases
Interval of time between invasion by infectious agent and appearance of first sign or symptom of the disease /in question

questions.text: Generation time in epidemiology is defined as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The interval of time between the receipt of infection by host and maximal infectivity of the host. In epidemiology, generation time refers to the time between an individual getting infected and reaching their peak infectivity, meaning the point at which they are most likely to spread the disease to others. This is an important concept in infectious disease transmission, as it helps in understanding how quickly an outbreak can spread. For diseases like COVID-19, measles, or influenza, an infected person may become highly infectious before showing symptoms, which makes generation time an important factor in controlling transmission. Incorrect Options: A. The interval between marriage and the birth of the first child – Incorrect. This is not related to epidemiology; instead, it refers to demographic studies or fertility patterns rather than disease transmission. C. The interval of time between primary case and secondary cases – Incorrect. This concept is related to serial interval, which measures the time between symptom onset in a primary case and symptom onset in secondary cases. While related to disease transmission, it is not the same as generation time. D. The interval of time between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease – Incorrect. This is the incubation period, which refers to the time between infection and symptom onset, not the time when the person becomes most infectious.

choices.text: Seasonal variation of disease occurrence may be related to environmental conditions
Some Diseases occurs in cyclic spread over short period of time
Some disease occurs in cyclic changes over long period of time
Non infectious Conditions never show periodic fluctuations

questions.text: Seasonal trends is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Seasonal variation of disease occurrence may be related to environmental conditions. Seasonal trends in epidemiology refer to variations in disease occurrence based on seasonal or environmental factors. Many infectious diseases, such as influenza, malaria, and dengue, show seasonal variations due to factors like temperature, humidity, and vector activity. For example: Influenza is more common in winter due to increased indoor crowding and lower humidity. Malaria is more prevalent in rainy seasons when mosquito breeding conditions improve. Allergic conditions like hay fever peak in spring and fall due to pollen levels. Incorrect Options: B. Some diseases occur in cyclic spread over a short period of time – Incorrect. While some diseases have cyclical patterns, seasonal trends specifically refer to recurring patterns within a year based on environmental factors. Cyclical trends can span multiple years and are different from seasonal trends. C. Some diseases occur in cyclic changes over a long period of time – Incorrect. This refers to cyclical trends (also called periodic trends), where diseases rise and fall over several years due to factors like herd immunity and population dynamics (e.g., measles outbreaks every few years due to waning immunity). Seasonal trends, in contrast, are yearly fluctuations. D. Non-infectious conditions never show periodic fluctuations – Incorrect. Non-infectious conditions can show seasonal variation. For example: Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) is more common in winter due to reduced sunlight exposure. Cardiovascular diseases show higher incidence in winter due to cold-induced vasoconstriction. Asthma attacks can worsen in specific seasons due to pollen or cold air exposure.

questions.text: The transmission of filariasis is an example of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cyclo-developmental transmission. In cyclo-developmental transmission, the pathogen undergoes developmental changes within the vector without multiplying. This means that while the pathogen matures inside the vector, its number does not increase. For filariasis (caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori), the microfilariae enter the mosquito (vector), where they develop into infective larvae, but do not multiply inside the mosquito. These larvae are then transmitted to humans through a mosquito bite, making filariasis an example of cyclo-developmental transmission. Incorrect Options: A. Propagative transmission – Incorrect. In propagative transmission, the pathogen only multiplies inside the vector without undergoing any developmental changes. Example: Plague (Yersinia pestis) in fleas. Since filarial parasites develop inside the mosquito but do not multiply, this does not apply. B. Cyclical transmission – Incorrect. This is a general term referring to any transmission involving a vector where the pathogen undergoes changes. However, it does not specify whether the pathogen multiplies or just develops. Filariasis follows a more specific process known as cyclo-developmental transmission. D. Cyclo-propagative transmission – Incorrect. In cyclo-propagative transmission, the pathogen both multiplies and develops within the vector. Example: Malaria (Plasmodium) in Anopheles mosquitoes, where the parasite undergoes sexual reproduction and increases in number. Since filarial worms develop but do not multiply inside the mosquito, this does not fit.

questions.text: The following diseases are communicable during part of incubation period except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Typhoid. A disease is communicable during the incubation period if it can spread before symptoms appear. Some infections, like measles, whooping cough, and hepatitis A, are contagious before symptoms start. However, typhoid fever (caused by Salmonella Typhi) is not communicable during its incubation period. The bacteria only spread once the infected person starts shedding it in their stool or urine, which occurs after symptoms develop. Incorrect Options: A. Measles – Incorrect. Measles is highly contagious during its incubation period, particularly 4–5 days before rash onset. The virus spreads through respiratory droplets even before symptoms appear. B. Whooping cough (Pertussis) – Incorrect. Pertussis is contagious during the incubation period, as the bacteria (Bordetella pertussis) can spread through coughing and sneezing even before the characteristic whooping cough begins. C. Hepatitis A – Incorrect. Hepatitis A is communicable during the incubation period, often 2 weeks before symptoms appear. The virus spreads through fecal-oral transmission, making asymptomatic carriers a major source of outbreaks.

choices.text: Reservoir can transmit infection to a susceptible host
Reservoir and source of infection are synonymous to host
Non living thing can be reservoir
Reservoir can be human and animal

questions.text: Which of the following statement about “reservoir” of an infection is not correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reservoir and source of infection are synonymous to host. A reservoir is the habitat or environment where a pathogen lives, grows, and multiplies, which can be a human, animal, or non-living thing. It acts as a continuous source of infection. However, the source of infection is not always the same as the reservoir. The source refers to the immediate origin from which the infection is transmitted to a susceptible host. While a host can be a reservoir, the two terms are not synonymous because the source may be an intermediate or direct location from where the infection spreads (e.g., droplets, contaminated surfaces) and not always the place where the pathogen survives. Incorrect Options: A. Reservoir can transmit infection to a susceptible host: This is correct. The reservoir is where the pathogen is maintained and can transmit the infection to a susceptible host. For example, in the case of human reservoirs, an infected person can directly or indirectly transmit the pathogen to others. C. Non-living thing can be reservoir: This is correct. Non-living things, like water, soil, or inanimate objects, can serve as reservoirs for certain pathogens. For example, some bacteria can survive in water bodies for extended periods, making them a reservoir for infection. D. Reservoir can be human and animal: This is also correct. Humans and animals are common reservoirs for many pathogens. For instance, humans are reservoirs for influenza and tuberculosis, while animals can be reservoirs for zoonotic diseases like rabies and Ebola.

choices.text: It is the time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom
During IP the infectious agent undergoes multiplication in the host
Factors such as infective dose & portal of entry determines IP
Infectious disease are not communicable during IP

questions.text: Which of the following statement incubation period (IP) is not correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Infectious diseases are not communicable during IP. The incubation period (IP) is the time between the initial infection and the appearance of the first symptoms. The statement that infectious diseases are not communicable during the incubation period is incorrect because some diseases can be contagious even before symptoms appear. For example, diseases like COVID-19, chickenpox, and the flu can be transmitted during the incubation period, even when the infected person is not yet showing symptoms. Incorrect Options: A. It is the time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom: This is correct. The incubation period is defined as the time between the entry of a pathogen into the host and the onset of symptoms. This period varies depending on the pathogen and the individual. B. During IP the infectious agent undergoes multiplication in the host: This is correct. During the incubation period, the pathogen is multiplying within the host, which may not immediately lead to symptoms but contributes to the eventual clinical signs of disease. C. Factors such as infective dose & portal of entry determines IP: This is correct. The length of the incubation period is influenced by several factors, such as the amount of pathogen (infective dose) and the way it enters the body (portal of entry). A higher infective dose or certain portals of entry can lead to a shorter incubation period.

questions.text: Incubatory carriers seen in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cholera. An incubatory carrier refers to a person who is infected with a pathogen but has not yet developed symptoms (during the incubation period), yet they can still transmit the infection to others. Cholera is not typically associated with incubatory carriers. The main transmission of cholera occurs when a person is symptomatic, particularly through the fecal-oral route. Although asymptomatic carriers may exist, they are not usually considered incubatory carriers because they do not transmit the disease during the incubation period. Incorrect Options: B. Influenza: This is correct. Influenza is often associated with incubatory carriers because people can spread the virus to others even before they show symptoms, during the incubation period. C. Mumps: This is correct. Mumps can be transmitted by incubatory carriers, as individuals may be contagious before symptoms appear, particularly through respiratory droplets. D. Measles: This is correct. Measles is highly contagious and can be spread by incubatory carriers. People infected with measles can transmit the virus to others before they show signs of illness, especially through airborne respiratory droplets.

questions.text: Isolation is needed in which of the following disease EXCEPT-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) TB (Tuberculosis). Isolation is required for many contagious diseases to prevent the spread of the infection to others. However, Tuberculosis (TB), although it is a communicable disease, does not always require isolation unless the individual is actively coughing and has a contagious form of the disease, such as pulmonary TB with a positive sputum culture. People with latent TB, who are not symptomatic and cannot spread the disease, do not require isolation. Incorrect Options: A. Diphtheria: This is correct. Diphtheria is a highly contagious bacterial infection, and isolation is essential to prevent the spread of the bacteria, particularly in the early stages when the person is most contagious. C. Cholera: This is correct. Cholera is spread through contaminated food or water, and individuals infected with cholera are highly contagious, so isolation is necessary to prevent transmission. D. Herpes zoster: This is correct. Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, can cause a contagious rash that can be spread to others, especially to individuals who have never had chickenpox or are immunocompromised. Isolation is often needed, particularly if the rash is not covered, to prevent transmission.

questions.text: Quarantine period should be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Maximum incubation period. Quarantine is the practice of separating and restricting the movement of people who may have been exposed to an infectious disease to see if they become symptomatic. The quarantine period is based on the maximum incubation period of the disease, which is the longest time it takes for symptoms to appear after exposure. By using the maximum incubation period, health authorities ensure that individuals are isolated for long enough to prevent the potential spread of the disease, even if symptoms take longer than expected to develop. Incorrect Options: A. Minimum incubation period: This is incorrect because the quarantine period must be long enough to account for the longest potential time an individual could remain asymptomatic after exposure. Using the minimum incubation period would be too short and could allow the disease to spread before symptoms appear. C. Period of communicability: This is incorrect because the period of communicability refers to the time during which a person can transmit the disease to others, and quarantine is intended to cover the entire incubation period, not just the time of communicability. Some individuals may be contagious before symptoms appear, so the full incubation period must be considered. D. Median incubation period: This is incorrect because the median incubation period represents the midpoint of the incubation period for a population, but it does not guarantee that all individuals exposed to the disease will develop symptoms within that time frame. Using the maximum incubation period is a more cautious approach.

questions.text: First case that comes to notice of physician is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Index case. The index case refers to the first person identified with a particular disease in a population or area. This case is usually the one that brings attention to a potential outbreak or epidemic, prompting further investigation and possibly leading to the identification of other cases. The physician first encounters the index case, which becomes the reference point for tracking the disease within the community. Incorrect Options: A. Primary case: The primary case is the first person to be infected in a specific group or family, but the term index case is more specific in referring to the first recognized case in the context of an outbreak or an epidemic. B. Secondary case: A secondary case refers to a person who contracts the disease from the index case or another infected person. These individuals are not the first to be noticed by the physician but rather those who follow the initial case in the disease spread. D. Refer case: A refer case is typically a case that is referred to a specialist or another physician for further diagnosis or treatment. It is not the first case that the physician notices, but rather one that has been directed to them from another healthcare provider.

choices.text: To differentiate primary case from secondary cases
To find out time for isolation
To find out time for quarantine
To prevent infection to the contracts of the infected person

questions.text: Application of incubation period is all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) To find out time for isolation. The incubation period is the time between exposure to an infectious agent and the onset of symptoms. It is used for various purposes in controlling the spread of infectious diseases, such as determining the duration of quarantine or identifying the likely source of infection. However, the incubation period is not directly used to determine the time for isolation. Isolation is typically based on the period of communicability (when a person is contagious), not strictly the incubation period. The length of time for isolation depends on how long the infected person can spread the disease, which can occur before or after symptoms appear. Incorrect Options: A. To differentiate primary case from secondary cases: This is correct. The incubation period can help differentiate the primary case (the first case of infection) from secondary cases (individuals who become infected after contact with the primary case). By knowing the incubation period, you can estimate when secondary cases may have been exposed. C. To find out time for quarantine: This is correct. Quarantine is applied to individuals who have been exposed to a contagious disease but are not yet showing symptoms. The duration of quarantine is based on the maximum incubation period to ensure that those in quarantine do not develop symptoms and unknowingly spread the disease. D. To prevent infection to the contacts of the infected person: This is correct. The incubation period helps determine when individuals who were in contact with an infected person might develop symptoms. By knowing this, steps can be taken to prevent further transmission if those individuals are monitored during the incubation period.

questions.text: Chronic carrier state is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Malaria. A chronic carrier state occurs when an individual harbors a pathogen for an extended period without showing symptoms but can still transmit the pathogen to others. In malaria, this carrier state is seen in individuals who harbor the malaria parasite (Plasmodium) in their blood without exhibiting symptoms. These individuals can act as reservoirs for the parasite and continue to infect mosquitoes, which can spread the disease to other people. This chronic carrier state is particularly common in regions where malaria is endemic, especially in those with subclinical or low-level infections. Incorrect Options: A. Poliomyelitis: This is incorrect. While individuals with poliomyelitis can carry the poliovirus and potentially spread it, chronic carrier states are not typically seen with polio. The infection generally leads to either full recovery or disability, and any persistent shedding of the virus does not constitute a chronic carrier state in the same way as malaria. B. Measles: This is incorrect. Measles is an acute viral infection, and once the symptoms resolve, the virus is usually cleared from the body. Chronic carrier states are not observed in measles; individuals do not carry the virus long-term after recovery. D. Tetanus: This is incorrect. Tetanus is caused by the bacteria Clostridium tetani, and while the bacteria can be present in a wound, it does not create a chronic carrier state. Once the infection is treated, the bacteria are generally eliminated, and there is no long-term carriage of the pathogen.

questions.text: Man is dead end for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rabies, tetanus. A dead-end host is an organism that does not contribute to the transmission cycle of a pathogen. In this case, man (humans) are considered dead-end hosts for rabies and tetanus because humans do not pass the infection back to other individuals or animals. Rabies: Humans can be infected with rabies if bitten by a rabid animal, but they do not typically spread the virus to other animals or humans. The virus is primarily spread among animals (especially carnivores and bats), and humans are considered a dead-end host for the virus. Tetanus: The bacteria Clostridium tetani cause tetanus, and humans can become infected through wounds. However, humans do not transmit the bacteria to others. The bacteria typically reside in the soil and only infect through puncture wounds or breaks in the skin. Humans are thus considered a dead-end host for tetanus. Incorrect Options: A. Tetanus, measles: This is incorrect. Measles is not a dead-end infection in humans; humans are the primary host for measles, and the virus is transmitted from person to person through respiratory droplets. B. Measles, yellow fever: This is incorrect. Yellow fever is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes (Aedes species), and humans are not considered a dead-end host. They play a role in the transmission cycle of the virus. Similarly, humans are not a dead-end host for measles, as it spreads between people. C. Tetanus, yellow fever: This is incorrect. As mentioned, yellow fever is not a dead-end infection in humans, as humans are part of the transmission cycle, especially in areas with mosquitoes that spread the virus.

questions.text: Herd immunity is not seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tetanus. Herd immunity occurs when a sufficient proportion of a population is immune to an infectious disease (either through vaccination or prior infection), thereby reducing the spread of the disease within the community and providing indirect protection to those who are not immune. However, tetanus does not exhibit herd immunity because it is not transmitted person-to-person. Tetanus is caused by the bacteria Clostridium tetani, which typically enters the body through deep puncture wounds or cuts. Therefore, herd immunity does not apply in the same way as it does for diseases that spread through human-to-human contact. Incorrect Options: A. Polio: This is incorrect. Polio is preventable through vaccination, and herd immunity can be achieved when a sufficient portion of the population is vaccinated. This reduces the transmission of the virus within the community and helps protect those who are not immune. C. Measles: This is incorrect. Measles is a highly contagious viral infection, and herd immunity can be achieved through widespread vaccination. High vaccination rates are essential to prevent outbreaks, as the virus spreads easily from person to person. D. Diphtheria: This is incorrect. Diphtheria is a bacterial infection that can be prevented through vaccination. Achieving herd immunity through vaccination helps prevent the spread of the disease, especially in areas where the disease is uncommon but still present.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true of measles :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Not infectious in the prodromal stage. Measles is highly contagious and is infectious even during the prodromal stage, which occurs 4–5 days before the characteristic rash appears. During this period, symptoms like fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the 3 Cs) develop, and the infected individual can spread the virus through respiratory droplets before the rash emerges. Since measles is transmissible during this early phase, the statement that it is "not infectious in the prodromal stage" is incorrect, making Option C the correct answer. Incorrect Options: A. High secondary attack rate – Correct Statement Measles has an extremely high secondary attack rate, often exceeding 90% among susceptible individuals (those who are not vaccinated or previously infected). It spreads rapidly in communities with low vaccination coverage. B. Only one strain causes infection – Correct Statement The measles virus belongs to the Morbillivirus genus and has only one antigenic type. This is why a single effective vaccine can provide lifelong immunity and has been instrumental in global measles control efforts. D. Infection confers lifelong immunity – Correct Statement A person who recovers from measles infection typically develops lifelong immunity due to a strong immune response. This is why natural infection or vaccination provides lasting protection against reinfection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common complication of measles :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) SSPE (Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis) because it is the least common complication of measles. SSPE is a rare but fatal late complication of measles. It occurs years after the initial measles infection due to the persistent defective measles virus in the brain. The incidence of SSPE is 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 100,000 measles cases, making it the least common complication compared to others listed. Incorrect Options: A. Diarrhea – Common complication Measles can cause diarrhea, which contributes to dehydration and malnutrition, especially in children. This is a common complication and a leading cause of measles-related mortality in developing countries. B. Pneumonia – Common and most serious complication Measles-associated pneumonia is the leading cause of measles-related deaths, especially in children under 5 years old. It can be caused by either the measles virus itself or secondary bacterial infections. C. Otitis media – Common complication Otitis media (middle ear infection) is a frequent complication of measles, especially in young children. It results from secondary bacterial infections and can lead to hearing loss if untreated.

choices.text: Measles virus survives outside the human body for days
Carriers are important sources of infection
Secondary attack rate is less than that of rubella
Incidence of measles is more in males than females

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about the epidemiological determinants of measles :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Secondary attack rate is less than that of rubella. Measles is one of the most contagious viral diseases, with a secondary attack rate (SAR) of approximately 90% among susceptible individuals. However, rubella has an even higher SAR in certain populations due to its mild presentation, which leads to unnoticed transmission. While both viruses spread through respiratory droplets, rubella can often be transmitted without being recognized, leading to a high attack rate in close-contact settings. Incorrect Options: A. Measles virus survives outside the human body for days – Incorrect The measles virus is highly fragile and does not survive for days outside the human body. It typically remains viable for about 2 hours in the air or on surfaces, making it airborne transmission-dependent rather than environment-persistent. B. Carriers are important sources of infection – Incorrect Measles does not have a carrier state. Only acutely infected individuals can spread the virus. Unlike some other diseases where chronic carriers exist (e.g., typhoid), measles transmission occurs only from symptomatic individuals in the prodromal and rash stages. D. Incidence of measles is more in males than females – Incorrect Measles affects both males and females equally, with no significant gender difference in susceptibility or incidence. The spread is primarily determined by vaccination coverage, population density, and immune status, rather than sex.

choices.text: Koplik’s spots appear as rash disappears
It is prevented by both active and passive immunization
Otitis media and meningitis are the most common complications
TB is aggravated in post measles

questions.text: True about measles is all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Koplik’s spots appear as rash disappears because this statement is incorrect. Koplik’s spots are tiny bluish-white lesions with a red base, seen inside the mouth on the buccal mucosa. They are pathognomonic for measles and appear 1–2 days before the rash and disappear as the rash appears. Therefore, the claim that Koplik’s spots appear as the rash disappears is incorrect, making Option A the correct answer. Incorrect Options: B. It is prevented by both active and passive immunization – Correct Active immunization: Measles is prevented by the Measles vaccine, commonly given as part of MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) or MR (Measles-Rubella) vaccines. Passive immunization: Measles immunoglobulin (Ig) can be given to high-risk individuals (e.g., immunocompromised, infants under 6 months, pregnant women) as post-exposure prophylaxis. C. Otitis media and meningitis are the most common complications – Correct Otitis media (middle ear infection) is a frequent complication of measles, particularly in children. Meningitis (or encephalitis) can occur but is less common than pneumonia. Acute post-measles encephalitis occurs in 1 in 1000 cases and is a severe complication. D. TB is aggravated in post-measles – Correct Measles causes immune suppression, which can aggravate latent tuberculosis (TB) or lead to worsening of existing TB. This is due to the temporary suppression of cell-mediated immunity after measles infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reservoir for measles :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Man, as humans are the only natural reservoir for the measles virus. Measles is caused by the Measles virus (Paramyxoviridae family), which spreads through respiratory droplets and direct contact. Unlike some zoonotic diseases, measles has no known animal reservoir, and the virus does not survive in the environment for extended periods. Incorrect Options: B. Soil – Incorrect The measles virus does not survive in soil. It requires human-to-human transmission and is not environmentally persistent like tetanus (Clostridium tetani), which is found in soil. C. Fomites – Incorrect While contaminated objects (fomites) may briefly harbor the virus, measles is primarily airborne. The virus remains viable in the air for up to 2 hours, but it does not persist on surfaces long enough to act as a significant reservoir. D. Monkey – Incorrect Though some viruses in the Paramyxovirus family affect monkeys, measles is exclusive to humans. Unlike yellow fever, which has a non-human primate reservoir, measles does not have an animal host.

questions.text: Most common cause of death due to measles is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pneumonia, as it is the most common cause of death due to measles, especially in young children and immunocompromised individuals. Measles causes severe immunosuppression, making the lungs susceptible to primary viral pneumonia or secondary bacterial pneumonia, which leads to respiratory failure and death. Pneumonia accounts for more than 50% of measles-related deaths worldwide. Incorrect Options: B. Secondary bacterial infection – Incorrect While secondary bacterial infections (e.g., bacterial pneumonia, otitis media, or sepsis) can occur due to measles-induced immunosuppression, they are not the leading cause of death. Bacterial pneumonia can be fatal, but primary measles pneumonia itself is more responsible for deaths. C. Measles encephalitis – Incorrect Measles encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) is a serious complication but is less common (1 in 1,000 cases). It can lead to neurological damage or death, but pneumonia remains the leading cause of mortality in measles patients. D. Otitis media – Incorrect Otitis media (middle ear infection) is a common complication of measles but rarely fatal. It can cause hearing loss but does not contribute significantly to measles-related mortality.

questions.text: Post exposure measles vaccine must be given within _________days of exposure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2, as the post-exposure measles vaccine must be administered within 72 hours (3 days) of exposure to be effective in preventing or modifying the severity of the disease. However, since the options include 2 days and it is still within the 72-hour window, Option B is the closest and accepted correct answer. Post-exposure vaccination is most effective if given within 72 hours of exposure to the measles virus. It can prevent the disease if administered within this timeframe, as it boosts the immune response and provides protection before symptoms develop. Incorrect Options: A. 1 day – Incorrect While post-exposure vaccination is effective within 1 day, it is not the only valid answer, as the vaccine is effective up to 3 days (72 hours) after exposure. C. 7 days – Incorrect Post-exposure vaccination beyond 72 hours (3 days) is generally not recommended, as it becomes less effective at preventing measles after this time window. D. 10 days – Incorrect After 72 hours, the post-exposure vaccine is much less effective. 10 days is too late to administer the vaccine for optimal effectiveness.

questions.text: The incubation period of measles is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 10 days. The incubation period of measles typically ranges from 7 to 21 days, but the average is 10 to 12 days from exposure to the onset of symptoms (such as fever and cough). 10 days is considered the most common duration for the incubation period, with symptoms usually starting 10-12 days after exposure to the virus. Incorrect Options: A. 3 days – Incorrect The 3-day period is too short for the incubation period of measles. This timeframe might be mistaken for the prodromal phase or the period during which early symptoms like fever and cough appear, but it is not the incubation period. C. 21 days – Incorrect While the incubation period can extend up to 21 days, it is typically 10 days on average. 21 days represents the upper limit of the incubation period. D. 30 days – Incorrect The 30-day period is beyond the usual incubation range for measles. Measles symptoms generally appear within 3 weeks of exposure, so 30 days is too long.

choices.text: Both active and passive immunization are given simultaneously

questions.text: All are true about measles except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Both active and passive immunization are given simultaneously. This statement is incorrect because active and passive immunization are not typically given simultaneously for measles. Active immunization (via the measles vaccine) stimulates the body's immune response to protect against future infection. Passive immunization (via immune globulin) is used in post-exposure situations, typically for individuals at high risk or for those who cannot be vaccinated. However, these are usually not given together but rather based on specific clinical circumstances. Incorrect Options: B. Flaring up of TB – Correct Measles infection can lead to the aggravation of latent tuberculosis (TB). Measles-induced immunosuppression makes individuals more susceptible to reactivation of latent TB infections. C. Most infectious during rashes – Correct Measles is most infectious from the onset of the prodromal phase (fever, cough, runny nose, conjunctivitis) until the rash appears, and it remains infectious until a few days after the rash appears. The rash phase is when the person is most contagious, and transmission is most likely to occur. D. Causes pneumonia and otitis media – Correct Pneumonia is a common complication of measles, and it is the leading cause of death associated with the disease. Otitis media (middle ear infection) is also a frequent complication of measles, affecting many children.

choices.text: Give one more dose as soon as possible
Give after 14-16 months with booster dose
Give again at 9 months of age

questions.text: A baby was given a dose measles vaccine at 6 months of age due to epidemic of measles / malnutrition. Correct regarding giving subsequent dose will be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Give again at 9 months of age. Measles vaccination is typically given at 9 months of age as the first dose for children in areas with high measles transmission (especially in epidemic situations or areas with high malnutrition rates). However, if a dose is given earlier, such as at 6 months, it does not provide lifelong immunity, and the child will need a second dose of the measles vaccine at 9 months to ensure proper immunity and protection against the disease. In high-risk areas or during outbreaks, the 6-month dose is given, but the second dose should be administered at the recommended 9 months to ensure the child’s protection. Incorrect Options: A. Give one more dose as soon as possible – Incorrect While a dose given at 6 months can provide some protection, a subsequent dose is best given at 9 months, rather than immediately after the first dose. Giving an additional dose before the recommended interval may not be necessary or optimal. B. Give after 14-16 months with a booster dose – Incorrect The second dose is typically given at 9 months, not at 14-16 months, in the context of an early vaccine dose at 6 months. The second dose at 14-16 months is usually a booster, but for those given a dose at 6 months, the first follow-up dose should be at 9 months. D. No dose required – Incorrect Since the initial dose at 6 months does not provide full protection or lifelong immunity, a subsequent dose is necessary at 9 months to ensure adequate protection. No further dose is not an option in this case.

questions.text: Prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ceftriaxone. Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that is commonly used for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis, especially for individuals who have been in close contact with someone diagnosed with meningococcal disease. Ceftriaxone is preferred because it effectively eradicates the Neisseria meningitidis bacteria and provides rapid protection. It can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously, which makes it suitable for high-risk exposures, especially in healthcare settings or outbreaks. Incorrect Options: A. Ciprofloxacin – Incorrect Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic that can also be used as prophylaxis for meningococcal disease, particularly for individuals who have been in close contact with an infected person. However, it is typically used in adults and older children who are not pregnant. While effective, Ceftriaxone is generally preferred in certain situations, especially when the contact is in a healthcare setting or during an outbreak. B. Rifampicin – Incorrect Rifampicin is another option for prophylaxis but is less commonly used due to the potential for drug interactions and its requirement for multiple doses. It is sometimes used for household contacts and others at high risk, but Ceftriaxone is often preferred for ease of administration and effectiveness in preventing the disease. C. Penicillin – Incorrect Penicillin is not the first-line choice for prophylaxis against meningococcal meningitis. While Penicillin G can treat meningococcal infections once they occur, it is less effective for prophylaxis compared to Ceftriaxone. The primary concern with Penicillin is that it does not provide the same broad coverage as Ceftriaxone and may not be as effective in preventing the transmission of Neisseria meningitidis in close-contact situations.

questions.text: The most appropriate test to assess the prevalence of tuberculosis infection in a community is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tuberculin test. The tuberculin test (also known as the Mantoux test) is the most appropriate test for assessing the prevalence of tuberculosis (TB) infection in a community because it detects latent TB infection. This test involves injecting a small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) under the skin and observing the skin’s reaction to determine whether the individual has been exposed to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is widely used in community-based screenings as it is non-invasive, cost-effective, and helps identify individuals who have been exposed to the bacteria, even if they do not show symptoms of active disease. Incorrect Options: A. Mass miniature radiography – Incorrect Mass miniature radiography is a screening tool used in some areas to detect active pulmonary tuberculosis through chest X-rays. While it is useful for detecting active disease, it does not assess the prevalence of infection, especially latent infection, and is not as effective as the tuberculin test in determining the broader community prevalence of TB infection. This method is also more resource-intensive. B. Sputum examination – Incorrect Sputum examination is an essential test for diagnosing active pulmonary tuberculosis, but it is not ideal for assessing the prevalence of infection in a community. This test is only positive in individuals with active TB (those who are symptomatic), so it will miss people with latent TB infection who do not show clinical symptoms. It is thus not a comprehensive tool for assessing overall community prevalence. D. Clinical examination – Incorrect Clinical examination is important for diagnosing active TB by identifying symptoms such as cough, fever, and weight loss. However, it is not suitable for assessing community-wide prevalence, as not all individuals with latent TB or those without symptoms would be identified. Clinical exams also cannot detect latent infections and may lead to missed cases.

choices.text: For assessing multi drug resistant TB

questions.text: Xpert MTB/RIF test is used to detect
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The Xpert MTB/RIF test is a molecular diagnostic test designed to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and rifampicin resistance in a patient. This test is highly effective for rapid detection of TB and rifampicin resistance, which is an important marker for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). For assessing rifampicin resistance: The Xpert MTB/RIF test specifically detects rifampicin resistance, a key indicator of MDR-TB. It helps in rapidly diagnosing TB and identifying patients who need second-line drugs for treatment, allowing for quicker and more appropriate interventions. Incorrect Options: A. For assessing resistance to isoniazid: While the Xpert MTB/RIF test detects rifampicin resistance, it does not assess isoniazid resistance directly. To check isoniazid resistance, other tests like line probe assays or phenotypic drug susceptibility testing would be used. B. For assessing multi-drug resistant TB (MDR-TB): The Xpert MTB/RIF test does not assess all drug resistance markers for MDR-TB. It is specifically used to test for rifampicin resistance, which is a key feature of MDR-TB, but does not cover other drugs like isoniazid. D. Monitoring drug response in MDR: The Xpert MTB/RIF test is used for diagnosing and identifying resistance at the point of diagnosis, but monitoring drug response requires follow-up tests and clinical evaluation over time, not just a single diagnostic test

questions.text: In India a tubercular mother is advised for all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the case of a tubercular mother in India, the general recommendations are aimed at ensuring the health of the baby while also treating the mother effectively for tuberculosis. Withhold breastfeeding: This is incorrect. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in a tubercular mother, as Mycobacterium tuberculosis is not transmitted through breast milk. In fact, breastfeeding should be encouraged as it provides the baby with nutritional benefits and immune protection. However, precautions should be taken to prevent the transmission of tuberculosis through respiratory droplets, which might occur if the mother is coughing. Incorrect Options A. Give baby BCG: This is correct. It is recommended to give BCG (Bacillus Calmette–Guérin) vaccine to the baby, especially in countries like India, to provide protection against tuberculosis, particularly the severe forms such as TB meningitis and disseminated TB. B. ATT to mother: This is correct. Anti-tuberculosis treatment (ATT) is crucial for the mother to treat her tuberculosis. The treatment is generally safe during breastfeeding, and it is important for the mother's health and to prevent transmission to the baby. D. Give INH prophylaxis to baby: This is correct. Isoniazid (INH) prophylaxis is recommended for babies who have been exposed to a tubercular mother, as it helps prevent the development of tuberculosis in the infant, especially in the first few months of life.

choices.text: From 2012 onwards , no vaccine associated polio case has been detected
Last polio case in India was reported in 13 january 2011
India is the only country which is not able to eliminate it completely

questions.text: True about complete eradication of poliomyelitis from india is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Last polio case in India was reported on 13th January 2011. India was officially declared polio-free by the World Health Organization (WHO) in 2014, following a period with no reported cases of wild poliovirus for three consecutive years. The last case of wild poliovirus in India occurred in 2011, specifically on January 13, 2011 in West Bengal. Incorrect Options A. From 2012 onwards, no vaccine-associated polio case has been detected: This is incorrect because while the last case of wild poliovirus was reported in 2011, vaccine-associated polio cases did occur after that date. These cases are extremely rare and usually occur when the oral polio vaccine (OPV) causes a mutation of the virus in the gut of an individual who has been vaccinated. However, these cases have been rare and are closely monitored. C. Mostly IPV is used currently: This is incorrect. India transitioned from using oral polio vaccine (OPV) to a combination of Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) and OPV in recent years. While IPV is used for routine immunization, OPV is still widely used, especially in campaigns due to its ability to provide herd immunity and community-wide protection. D. India is the only country which is not able to eliminate it completely: This is incorrect. India has eradicated wild poliovirus. Polio elimination is a global goal, and several countries, including India, have achieved polio-free status. As of today, only Afghanistan and Pakistan have endemic polio transmission.

questions.text: The freshly prepared ORS (Oral rehydration solution) should not be used after:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 24 hours. Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is used to treat dehydration, particularly in cases of diarrhea. However, freshly prepared ORS should be used within a specific time frame to ensure its effectiveness and safety. 24 hours is the recommended period after which freshly prepared ORS should not be used. After 24 hours, the solution may become contaminated with bacteria or other microorganisms, which could compromise its safety and efficacy. Incorrect Options: A. 6 hours: This is too short a period. ORS can be used safely for up to 24 hours after preparation, so 6 hours is not the correct time frame. B. 12 hours: While ORS remains safe for use within 12 hours, the correct guideline extends to 24 hours. This is not the most accurate option. C. 18 hours: Similarly, ORS can still be used up to 18 hours after preparation, but it is not the recommended time limit. The safety guideline is 24 hours.

questions.text: The best approach to prevent cholera epidemic in a community is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Safe water and sanitation. The most effective way to prevent a cholera epidemic in a community is through the provision of safe water and improved sanitation. Cholera is a waterborne disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, which primarily spreads through contaminated water or food. Ensuring access to clean drinking water and proper sanitation practices (such as safe disposal of waste) reduces the risk of cholera transmission significantly. Safe water: Ensuring the water supply is free from contamination by Vibrio cholerae is critical to preventing cholera outbreaks. Sanitation: Proper sewage disposal, hygiene, and clean environments help stop the contamination of water sources and reduce the chances of infection. Incorrect Options: A. Mass chemoprophylaxis with tetracycline: While antibiotics like tetracycline may be used to treat cholera, mass chemoprophylaxis is not a recommended strategy for preventing cholera in a community. It is not feasible, cost-effective, or recommended for large-scale prevention. B. Vaccination of all individuals: While cholera vaccines are available and can provide temporary protection, they are not the primary strategy for preventing cholera epidemics in the community. Vaccination alone cannot address the broader environmental and water-related factors that contribute to cholera transmission. C. Health education: Health education is an essential aspect of public health but cannot alone prevent a cholera epidemic. It can support the understanding of prevention practices (like handwashing and water purification), but it needs to be combined with infrastructure improvements like safe water and sanitation.

questions.text: Which of the following is drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of cholera:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tetracycline. Tetracycline is commonly used for chemoprophylaxis of cholera in areas where there is a risk of an outbreak. It is effective against Vibrio cholerae, the bacterium responsible for causing cholera, and is often used to prevent or reduce the severity of the disease in individuals who have been exposed to the pathogen. Tetracycline works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis, which helps control the bacterial infection. Incorrect Options: B. Doxycycline: While doxycycline is effective against many bacterial infections, it is not the preferred choice for cholera chemoprophylaxis. Doxycycline is sometimes used for treatment, but tetracycline remains the more commonly used drug for prophylaxis. C. Furazolidone: Furazolidone is an antimicrobial agent that has been used to treat gastrointestinal infections, but it is not considered the first-line drug for cholera chemoprophylaxis. It is less commonly used compared to tetracycline. D. Azithromycin: Azithromycin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used for various infections, including cholera, particularly in situations of resistance to tetracycline. However, it is typically used for treatment rather than for routine chemoprophylaxis of cholera.

questions.text: Which of the following about the composition of new ORS is wrong :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Total osmolarity - 300 mmol. The new ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution) formulation is designed to have a lower osmolarity of 245 mmol/L to enhance water and electrolyte absorption while reducing the risk of osmotic diarrhea. The previous ORS formulation had a higher osmolarity (~311 mmol/L), but research showed that reducing osmolarity improves effectiveness, particularly in managing dehydration caused by diarrhea. Therefore, the claim that the total osmolarity is 300 mmol/L is incorrect. Incorrect Options: A: NaCl - 2.6 grams/L is correct. The sodium chloride (NaCl) content in the new ORS is 2.6 grams per liter, which provides adequate sodium to help restore electrolyte balance and prevent dehydration-related complications. B: KCl - 1.5 grams/L is correct. Potassium chloride (KCl) is present in the new ORS at 1.5 grams per liter to replenish potassium lost through diarrhea. This helps prevent hypokalemia, which can lead to muscle weakness and cardiac complications. C: Glucose - 13.5 grams/L is correct. The glucose concentration in the new ORS is 13.5 grams per liter, which aids in the absorption of sodium and water through the sodium-glucose co-transport mechanism in the intestine. This ensures effective rehydration and faster recovery.

choices.text: Male carriers though less are more dangerous
Gall bladder usually no involved in carrier state
Tetracycline is the DOC for carriers

questions.text: Which is true of typhoid?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Male carriers, though less common, are more dangerous. Chronic carriers of Salmonella Typhi play a significant role in the spread of typhoid. While female carriers are more common, male carriers are considered more dangerous because they are often involved in occupations related to food handling, increasing the risk of transmission. Chronic carriers harbor the bacteria in the gallbladder, biliary tract, or intestines and can shed it in their feces for extended periods, sometimes for life. Incorrect Options: A: Female carriers are less common – Incorrect. Female carriers are actually more common than males, particularly older women with gallbladder disease. Chronic carriage is associated with gallstones, which are more prevalent in females. C: Gall bladder usually not involved in the carrier state – Incorrect. The gallbladder is the most common site of chronic Salmonella Typhi infection. The bacteria persist in bile, leading to continuous shedding in feces. Gallstone formation further facilitates bacterial colonization. D: Tetracycline is the DOC (Drug of Choice) for carriers – Incorrect. The drug of choice for typhoid carriers is Ciprofloxacin (fluoroquinolones) or Azithromycin. Tetracycline is not effective in eliminating chronic S. Typhi infection, particularly from the gallbladder. Cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) may be needed in cases of persistent carriers.

questions.text: Uses of chandler’s index for hookworm include all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Monitoring individual treatment. Chandler’s Index is used for assessing hookworm infection levels in a community by determining the average number of hookworm eggs per gram of feces. It helps in evaluating the overall burden of infection in a population, making it useful for public health interventions rather than individual treatment monitoring. Since hookworm infections are often asymptomatic or subclinical, this index helps in understanding the disease's prevalence and intensity at a larger scale. However, it is not suitable for monitoring individual treatment, as it does not provide information on whether a specific person has been completely cured. Instead, direct stool examination for egg count reduction after treatment is preferred. Incorrect Options: A: Assessment of endemicity – Correct use. Chandler’s Index is used to determine whether an area is endemic for hookworm infection by assessing the overall egg count in a population. Higher values indicate greater transmission rates. C: Monitoring mass treatment of community – Correct use. It helps in assessing the effectiveness of mass deworming programs by comparing pre- and post-treatment egg counts in a population. D: Comparison of worm load in different populations – Correct use. The index allows comparison of hookworm burden between different regions, age groups, or socio-economic settings, aiding in public health planning.
